I've always wanted to know how much distance a large bipedal carnivorous dinosaur (such as tyrannosaurus rex) and a large quadrupedal herbivore (such as apatosaurus) could cover in a single stride whilst moving at full speed.

If say a bengal tiger at full tick is covering, let's say for arguments sake, 8 feet per stride and again, for arguments sake, is clocked at an average speed of 35mph, then wouldn't a tyrannosaurus who (arguments sake), covers let's say 15 feet per stride at a maximum speed of 20mph, isn't the tyrannosaurus therefore faster than the tiger based on distance covered?

Cheetahs may be faster, but they suck in endurance. While yes a cheetah can easily reach 60-70 MPH, they can't maintain that speed for more than about 15-20 seconds as they will get so hot they risk overheating their brains. A Tyrannosaurus Rex though has a far superior internal cooling and respiratory system such that it could maintain it's top speed for longer and with less stress to the body than what a cheetah does. For all my nerd friends out there, they may remember in one of the old Thundercats cartoons this was how Lion-o was able to defeat Cheetara in the contest of speed when he had to prove himself the true "Lord of the Thundercats".

Call me out if I'm wrong, but I've heard that T-Rex couldn't actually run at all. Juveniles could run while they were smaller, but once they passed a certain size threshold their legs just wouldn't have been physically capable of handling the extra force that it would take to push itself off the ground that fast. It wouldn't necessarily take a cheetah to outrun the Tyrant. But then again, it could probably brisk walk at speeds up to 25mph (~40kph), and likely had a bite force equivalent to about 3 mini coopers stacked on top of each other, so...I wouldn't get too cocky.

They're fast because their main pray (Thomson gazelles, Springbok antilope, etc) is fast. Only the fastest cheetahs ate and thus survived to pass their genes. But the same thing happened  to the pray - it had to be fast to escape the cheetahs so only the fastest gazelles and antilopes survived to pass their genes. If the parents are the fastest, than the offsprings will be faster on average than previous generations. But if the pray is faster, the predator needs to be faster if it is to survive, so again the fastest chettah survived to make even faster offsprings. It's a vicious circle that forced both the cheetah and its pray to become the fastest land animals. Stupid competition, they're in the same spot they would have been had they run slower, but now they waste more energy. On the plus side, both cheetahs and their pray can easily escape other predators.

Contrary to popular belief, Tyrannosaurus Rex was an exceptionally gifted natural at playing the piano. Unfortunately this talent here having found it's elolutionary pinnacle didn't come into fruition in the form of any classical works because none of these dimwitted animals ever thought to record their sessions, simply playing the notes by striking taunt lianas with their, for the purpose, superbly formed little forearms as they passed them by in the dense jungles of the primordial earth - and also because none of the other creatures they shared the world with had much patience for sitting around listening to them playing being somewhat unwholesomely engrossed in the whole survival-of-the-fittest shenanigans that went on at the time.

When timemachines becomes commercially available in 2044, this luckily will be rectified and the world will at last be able to enjoy the majestic piano suits of these magnificent, finely tuned musical naturals.

Grrrr... This video pisses me off. Great, you mention the flexibility of the spine helping to maximize the length of the stride. You then mention the swiveling hips, but don't even mention why that's important? You could have talked less about the T. Rex, and talked about how when the cheetah's spine flexes the hips allow it's paws to go further forward under the body. When the spine recoils it propels the legs back further extending the cheetah's stride. Basically, the cheetah uses its spine as a spring to help propel it. I could be crazy, but I think that is important.

I'll take heart not that the t-rex would win in the fight, but that the cheetah could escape; I'd rather have both of those creatures alive, not just one!
Still, nicely informative & fun video!

Meanwhile the humans just keep on moving and wear their prey down till its too tired to run anymore.

Why... don't you bring up that a Cheetah has a hard time maintaining it's top speed? Just because it can reach it doesn't mean it can sustain it or go there without penalty either. The reason why it's something they do at all is because of how hard it is for them to survive without it. Other cats in the same biome can either outlast or sneak on a target. They aren't as bulky so they need to catch their prey and also eat before they get bullied out of it.
Yes Cheetah would outrun a T-rex... until the Cheetah was fatigued. Then it would get eaten because even though the Cheetah went faster, if the Cheetah doesn't hide in order to reset, the T-rex would with it's standard movements catch up in no time.

So a T. Rex would never reach it's maximum potential speed, because it would use up its reserves of energy during acceleration? It sounds like what the T. Rex needed was some method of boosting its acceleration, which the T. Rex could then leave behind once it had adequate momentum. I propose a pair of solid fuel boosters mounted to the T. Rex's sides, which would accelerate it laterally, then once they run out, could be decoupled. I am suggesting we create a rocket-propelled T. Rex. This would allow the T. Rex to achieve its maximum possible speed, which would easily allow it to run down that jeep from Jurassic Park, and would probably help it avoid extinction somehow.

When dealing with millions of years ago, you can maybe have an idea of speeds attainable but accuracy will falter, considering Gravity was not as strong as the 9.8m/s/s we currently live with, meaning atmospheric pressure would also be lower along with friction.
Sadly, I can't find the right value at the moment, but lower gravity along with abundance of food and oxygen are probably the biggest contributors to why animals were allowed to grow so large some 250 million years ago.
Hearts have significant trouble pumping blood as gravity increases. And bigger hearts rarely make things more efficient.
